It is the policy of Citco Water, Inc. (CWI) Bridgeport, West Virginia facility management to implement the requirements of this Risk Management Program (RMP) in accordance with the USEPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68 Risk Management Program Level 3. The objective is to minimize the risk of a release of a hazardous material and if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to CWI employees, the public and the environment. This objective will be accomplished by utilizing best management practices, providing appropriate training to all employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with

the local emergency response providers. CWI management is committed to providing the resources necessary to implement this policy.



The Bridgeport, WV facility is governed by a set of USEPA regulations that require planning and facility activities intended to prevent a release of hazardous material, or if a release inadvertently occurs, to minimize the consequences of a release to the employees of the facility, the public and to the environment. These regulations include: 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention 40 CFR Part 302, Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) The key concepts in CWI release prevention program are employee participation, appropriate maintenance of equipment, and appropriate training of all employees. Employee participation in the release prevention program is encouraged and supported by CWI management. Key personnel are responsible for conducting and implementing the findings from the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage. CWI is committed to providing appropriate training to all employees regarding safety procedures. New employees are provided comprehensive safety training during their initial orientation for the facility. In addition, CWI conducts regularly scheduled safety training for all employees each year.



Location and Background

CWI operates an industrial supply dis

tribution center at this location. Chlorine and sulfur dioxide cylinders are received, stored, and shipped to public and private water and wastewater treatment facilities. Two chemicals, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide are stored at the facility in sufficient quantities to be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68. The facility stores 150-pound and 2,000-pound cylinders of chlorine, and 150-pound and 2,000-pound cylinders of sulfur dioxide. Chlorine and sulfur dioxide detection systems are present at the facility.



Five-Year Release History

No incidents to report.



Emergency Response Program

Certain abnormal situations require rapid and correct response to limit the potential for personnel injury, damage to plant equipment or the environment. The emergency response program is intended to provide a description of necessary responses and assigned duties for designated personnel to minimize effects of the emergency incident. This response plan is specific to a chemical release, which would have the potential to cause risk to the public or the environment.
